title: fanoutqa: What is the predominant religion practiced in countries where there have been recorded instances of raining fish, and which religion's followers experience this phenomenon the most? (d7ab22740996aea9)

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>Rain of animals</title>
<fragment>
27. **^** "Fish rain takes Kerala villagers by surprise". *The Financial Express*. 14 February 2008.
28. **^** "Fish Rain", reported in the India : [2], October 24, 2009
29. **^** "It's raining fish in Northern Territory", reported in news.com.au : [3], February 28, 2010
30. **^** Lani Nami Buan (15 January 2012). "It's raining fish! It's normal". GMA News. Retrieved 16 January 2012.
31. **^** Jereco O. Paloma (15 January 2012). "Agusan's 'rain of fish' natural although unusual". SunStar Davao. Retrieved 16 January 2012.
32. **^** "Fish Rain", reported in the India : [4], September 12, 2013
33. **^** "Fish rain down on Sri Lanka village, reported in https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia : [5], 6 May 2014
34. **^** Archived August 14, 2015, at the Wayback Machine[*dead link*]
35. **^** Villagers wake up to find fish in fields!, *The Times of India*, August 17, 2015
36. **^** "Fish rain in diredawa Ethiopia.", http://mereja.com/news/1080799

</fragment>
<fragment>

After a reported rain of fish in Singapore in 1861, French naturalist Francis de Laporte de Castelnau speculated that a migration of walking catfish had taken place, dragging themselves over land from one puddle to another, following the rain.[7]


The likeliest explanation for many of the supposed cases is that there is no falling happening at all and the animals are driven along by winds or a deluge of some sort.[8] This explanation also accounts for the prevalence of reports that only a single species or type of animal is ever reported raining from the sky.


</fragment>
<fragment>
Reported meteorological phenomenon

![](image)A rain of fish was recorded in Singapore in 1861, when during three days of torrential rain numerous fish were found in puddles
![](image)Raining snakes, 1680.
A **rain of animals** is a rare meteorological phenomenon in which flightless animals fall from the sky. Such occurrences have been reported in many countries throughout history.[1] One hypothesis is that tornadic waterspouts sometimes pick up creatures such as fish or frogs, and carry them for up to several miles.[1][2] However, this aspect of the phenomenon has never been witnessed by scientists.[3]




## History[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Rain of flightless animals and things has been reported throughout history.[1] In the first century AD, Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder documented storms of frogs and fish.[4] In 1794, French soldiers saw toads fall from the sky during heavy rain at Lalain, near the French city of Lille.[5] Rural inhabitants in Yoro, Honduras claim "fish rain" happens there every summer, a phenomenon they call Lluvia de Peces.[6]



## Explanations[edit]


![](image)Tornadoes and waterspouts may lift up animals into the air and deposit them miles away
French physicist André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836) was among the first scientists to take seriously accounts of raining animals. Addressing the Society of Natural Science, Ampère suggested that at times frogs and toads roam the countryside in large numbers, and that violent winds could pick them up and carry them great distances.[3]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Some cases are thought to be caused by birds dropping fish. With regard to a documented rain of fish that occurred on December 29, 2021 in Texarkana, Texas, independent researchers Sharon A. Hill and Paul Cropper proposed that the fish had been dropped or possibly regurgitated by passing birds.[20] The theory found some favor with airport workers who had cleaned up the fish; they noted that there were birds in the area around the same time, and the fish "were kind of chewed up". In June 2022 around the San Francisco coast, a boom of anchovies is likely to be the cause of fair weather falling of fish from birds' mouths, such as pelicans.[21]



## Occurrences[edit]


The following list is a selection of examples.

</fragment>

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>Christianity by country</title>
<fragment>

Christianity is the predominant religion and faith in Europe, the Americas, the Philippines, East Timor, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Oceania.[12] There are also large Christian communities in other parts of the world, such as Indonesia, Central Asia, the Middle East, and West Africa where Christianity is the second-largest religion after Islam. The United States has the largest Christian population in the world, followed by Brazil, Mexico, Russia, and the Philippines.[13]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Christianity in multiple forms is the state religion of the following 15 nations: Argentina (Catholic Church),[14] Armenia (Armenian Apostolic Church), Tuvalu (Church of Tuvalu), Costa Rica (Catholic Church),[15] Kingdom of Denmark (Evangelical Lutheran Church in Denmark),[16] England (Church of England),[17] Greece (Church of Greece), Georgia (Eastern Orthodox Church),[18][19] Iceland (Church of Iceland),[20] Liechtenstein (Catholic Church),[21] Malta (Catholic Church),[22] Monaco 
(Catholic Church),[23] Vatican City (Catholic Church),[24] and Zambia. Christianity used to be the state religion of the former Ethiopian Empire (adopted in 340 A.D. by the Kingdom of Aksum) prior to the government's overthrow.[25]

## Notes[edit]


1. **^** Current sources are in general agreement that Christians make up about 33% of the world's population—slightly over 2.4 billion adherents in mid-2015.
2. **^** Tunisia's Ministry of Religious Affairs estimates there are approximately 30,000 Christians residing in the country, of which the majority are foreigners and about 80% of whom are Roman Catholic. Approximately 7000 Christians are Tunisian Citizens, mostly Anglicans and other Protestants.[169]

## References[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

As of the year 2021, Christianity had approximately 2.38 billion adherents and is the largest religion by population respectively.[2][3] According to a PEW estimation in 2020, Christians made up to 2.38 billion of the worldwide population of about 8 billion people.[a][4][5][6][7][8][9] It represents nearly one-third of the world's population and is the largest religion in the world, with the three largest groups of Christians being the Catholic Church, Protestantism, and the Eastern Orthodox Church.[10] The largest Christian denomination is the Catholic Church, with 1.3 billion baptized members.[11] The second largest Christian branch is either Protestantism (if it is considered a single group), or the Eastern Orthodox Church (if Protestants are considered to be divided into multiple denominations).


</fragment>
<fragment>

#### Christian-majority countries and territories[edit]


According to a 2012 Pew Research Center study, of the then 232 countries and territories, 157 had Christian majorities. 126 countries had a Christian majority, while 71 countries had a Christian minority.[200]

Countries by highest percentage of the population that is Christian with at least 10 million Christians:[200]






</fragment>
<fragment>

**Note**: Population data are compiled using statistical science and are subject to observational error; these numbers should therefore be considered estimates only. The total number of Christians for each country is based on the number of people who are members of a Christian denomination or who identify themselves as Christian, plus their children. The number of people who actually believe in God or who regularly attend church is not addressed. People who mix Christianity with tribal religions are counted as Christians in this article. Most of the numbers for the Christian percentage of the population for each country were taken from the US State Department's *International Religious Freedom Report*, the *CIA World Factbook*, Joshua Project, Open doors, Pew Forum, and Adherents.com.

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
The phenomenon of "raining fish" has been reported in various countries, including:

- India
- Sri Lanka
- Singapore
- Honduras
- Ethiopia
- United States (e.g., Texarkana, Texas)

The predominant religion in these countries varies:

1. **India**: Hinduism
2. **Sri Lanka**: Buddhism
3. **Singapore**: Buddhism, with significant populations of Christians, Muslims, and Hindus
4. **Honduras**: Christianity (predominantly Roman Catholic)
5. **Ethiopia**: Christianity (predominantly Ethiopian Orthodox)
6. **United States**: Christianity (predominantly Protestant)

From the list, Christianity appears to be the predominant religion in Honduras, Ethiopia, and the United States, where instances of raining fish have been recorded. Therefore, followers of Christianity experience this phenomenon the most.
